pr_title: [Analytics] Add api to attach user information to the endpoint

timeline.message: Add api to attach user information to the endpoint
Add api to attach user information to the endpoint

timeline.bodyText: If you make this nullable, add a note to the javadoc about what happens when it is null / what the null means.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText:
Right now, if userProfile is null, then it will get passed down into addUserProfileToEndpoint(...), where userProfile.getSomething() happens, and will generate aNullPointerException.
So, either you should guard if (userProfile != null) { useIt(); }, or you should dis-allow null by requireNonNull(...) immediately after receiving the value.
It's possible that null for htis param is supposed to mean "clear the identified user."?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

replies.bodyText: Added null check for userProfile. userProfile = null means that the endpoint will have userId as the only information about the user and nothing more.
replies.author: desokroshan

timeline.bodyText: All of these things that return a Builder will all return @NonNull, too. Might as well add it everywhere you can on public/protected members. It makes a big help for Kotlin code that calls this stuff.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.message: Add nullity annotations and apply other feedback

timeline.bodyText: nit: to help break up the groupings, add an empty line after the constants, before the Application declaration.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: This class is final, and can't be extended. So protected isn't of much value, here. I think maybe you want just default package-local access, here?
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: If you make this as private UserProfile(Builder builder), then only you will be able to call this constructor, and you don't have to worry about the builder being null (you'll be able to ensure that, with your own code in this file.)
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText: Same deal here, you can probably make this private Location(Builder builder), and then as long as you always pass non-null from build(), you don't need to check Objects.requireNonNull(...), since that's the only single place it'll ever be possible.
timeline.author: jamesonwilliams
jamesonwilliams
